channel.title: Comments on: jQuery Edit In Place (JEIP)

item.title: By: Inplace Editing – Fast Gallery – wordpress-15123-47510-124403.cloudwaysapps.com
item.dc:creator: Inplace Editing – Fast Gallery – wordpress-15123-47510-124403.cloudwaysapps.com
item.description: […] Feature basiert auf dem jQuery Edit in Place Plugin, welches separat heruntergeladen und installiert werden […]
item.content:encoded: […] Feature basiert auf dem jQuery Edit in Place Plugin, welches separat heruntergeladen und installiert werden […]

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/code/javascript/jquery-edit-in-place/#comment-313">Paula RB</a>.
If you are still getting the error then something is preventing the jQuery object from being created.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Paula RB.

If you are still getting the error then something is preventing the jQuery object from being created.

item.title: By: Paula RB
item.dc:creator: Paula RB
item.content:encoded:
Oops I should have known better than putting script tags on my comment. I’m importing the following in this order:
“//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.0/jquery.min.js”

window.jQuery || document.write(‘scripting tag src=”../assets/js/jquery.min.js” scripting tag’))

and then I include jeip.js and I double checked the directories and paths are correct.

item.title: By: Paula RB
item.dc:creator: Paula RB
item.content:encoded:
It is, I’m actually importing it from a local file and from the Google APIs

// Fall back to a local copy of jQuery if the CDN fails
window.jQuery || document.write(”))

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/code/javascript/jquery-edit-in-place/#comment-310">Paula RB</a>.
You need to make sure that jQuery is loaded before the jeip.js code.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Paula RB.

You need to make sure that jQuery is loaded before the jeip.js code.

item.title: By: Paula RB
item.dc:creator: Paula RB
item.description:
Thanks for such an awesome feature! I'm aware you haven't worked on this code for a while which is totally fine - I have a very newbie question (I've only been coding for a couple of years and am just entering the JQuery world).
I included the jeip.js file in my code and added the simple tag just to try to out ($("#username").eip("save.php"); ) in the of the html file but the console spits the error 'ReferenceError: jQuery is not defined on jeip.js 323'. Am supposed to write my jquery on jeip.js?
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for such an awesome feature! I’m aware you haven’t worked on this code for a while which is totally fine – I have a very newbie question (I’ve only been coding for a couple of years and am just entering the JQuery world).

I included the jeip.js file in my code and added the simple tag just to try to out ($(“#username”).eip(“save.php”); ) in the of the html file but the console spits the error ‘ReferenceError: jQuery is not defined on jeip.js 323’. Am supposed to write my jquery on jeip.js?

item.title: By: Benjamin Sandmann
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Sandmann
item.description: Np, you've done all of the heavy lifting; I can just add it in myself. Thanks for building this and posting it online!
item.content:encoded: Np, you’ve done all of the heavy lifting; I can just add it in myself. Thanks for building this and posting it online!

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/code/javascript/jquery-edit-in-place/#comment-307">Benjamin Sandmann</a>.
That would be a nice feature to have. I haven't done anything with this code in a long time, it isn't likely to get updated any time soon.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Benjamin Sandmann.

That would be a nice feature to have. I haven’t done anything with this code in a long time, it isn’t likely to get updated any time soon.

item.title: By: Benjamin Sandmann
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Sandmann
item.description: Your in-place editor is amazing, but I didn't see an option for a callback function instead of an AJAX callout. Is there any reason to not give the user more control over their I/O and simply have them return a string after they're done (the String would represent the HTML you would use as if the AJAX response had returned in your other examples).
item.content:encoded: Your in-place editor is amazing, but I didn’t see an option for a callback function instead of an AJAX callout. Is there any reason to not give the user more control over their I/O and simply have them return a string after they’re done (the String would represent the HTML you would use as if the AJAX response had returned in your other examples).

item.title: By: Justin
item.dc:creator: Justin
item.description: Is there a way to check if the origin value matches on of the select options? I'd like to have the right option selected upon initiating the plugin.
item.content:encoded: Is there a way to check if the origin value matches on of the select options? I’d like to have the right option selected upon initiating the plugin.
